Body:
PM-BUDGET-NYT 
 (sw) 
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

     For TUESDAY PMs  

   Here are the top news stories from The New York Times News
Service for PMs of Tuesday, March 7.

   The PMs news desk, 212-556-1927, opens at 7 a.m. Eastern Time.
To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns
on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI
DataNews.

     INTERNATIONAL _ (Moved in ``i'' category)   

   CHINA-ASSESS (Shanghai, China) _ News Analysis: China's renewed
threat of war against Taiwan has caused anxiety in the West, but
Beijing's military options for attacking the island remain limited
and impractical, a fact often overlooked amid the furor in
Washington. Beijing's vow to use force, made in a policy paper last
month and repeated in an editorial in a military newspaper today,
is meant to warn Taiwan away from formal independence and push it
toward serious negotiations on reunification with the mainland. A
news analysis by Craig S. Smith.

   (ART ADV: Map has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

   PALESTINIANS-POET (Ramallah, West Bank) _ Mahmoud Darwish, the
poet whose lyrical writings have long been a touchstone of
Palestinian national passions, was banned from Israel and the
occupied territories for nearly 30 years. Now he finds himself
watching _ still from afar, but with considerable bemusement _ as
his poetry becomes a weapon in the hands of right-wing Israeli
politicians who would like to bring down the government. By Susan
Sachs.

   (ART ADV: Map has been sent to NYT graphics clients.)

     NATIONAL _ GENERAL (Moved in ``a'' category)  

   MISSILE-DEFENSE (Undated) _ A former senior engineer at TRW, a
top military contractor, has charged the company with faking tests
and evaluations of a key component for the proposed $27 billion
antimissile system and then firing her when she protested. By
William J. Broad.

   (ART ADV: Photos [NYT27,28) have been sent to NYT photo clients.
Graphic has been sent to NYT graphics clients.)

   BOEING-STRIKE (Tukwila, Wash.) _ The placards along the picket
lines outside the Boeing Co.'s huge aircraft plants are a bit
unusual. ``No Nerds, No Birds,'' proclaims one. And many Boeing
engineers, most on strike for the first time in their lives, say
they are still stunned at how unified their group has become in the
face of its protest against the jet manufacturer. The increasingly
bitter protest by the Society of Professional Engineering Employees
in Aerospace has mushroomed into one of the largest strikes by
white-collar workers against a private company in years. For
national labor leaders, who have rushed in to help out the striking
engineers, the strike is clearly seen as an opportunity to make
inroads in its hopes to organize a potentially vast sector of the
workforce. By Sam Howe Verhovek.

   NY-PLANETARIUM (New York) _ Turns out, it really is rocket
science. Since the Rose Center for Earth and Space opened last
month, visitors have lined up with enthusiasm. And, sometimes, they
have left in confusion. As one woman complained, ``My brain hurt
when I was done.'' And that is why six months ago the center hired
a small museum in Connecticut to help with a solution. By Tina
Kelley.

   (ART ADV: Photo has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

     CAMPAIGN _ (Moved in ``p'' category)  

   BUSH-NY (New York) _ A look at how the New York Republican
establishment got so tied up with George W. Bush. By Adam
Nagourney.

   GEORGIA-VOTERS (Covington, Ga.) _ If previous elections were a
blur of policy headlines and angry demands, this year's is more
like an interesting novel that local voters suddenly have the time
and the wherewithal to read. There is a plot, and they are in it.
There's not much doubt who will win Tuesday's primaries in Georgia;
both Bush and Gore are enormously popular here, and none of the
four major candidates has even bothered to campaign here on a
regular basis. But neither inevitability nor prosperity seems to
have dimmed Newton County's interest in this election. No one here
has seen a single political ad or shaken a candidate's hand, yet
voters are planning to show up at the polls, and they won't be
making a decision in last-minute frustration. By David Firestone.

     BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)   

   INTERNET-MUSIC (Undated) _ The music industry is already plenty
disturbed about the popularity of MP3, a technology that poses a
serious piracy threat by compressing music into files that can be
close to CD quality yet small enough to travel quickly over the
Internet. But Napster, a new online service, greatly magnifies the
threat that MP3 files pose to music copyrights by creating an
international exchange for swapping recordings _ often in far less
time than it takes to play the music. By Amy Harmon.

   NKOREA-INVEST (Mount Kumgang, North Korea) _ A few miles north
of the demilitarized zone that has divided the Korean peninsula for
nearly half a century, Hyundai Group, the largest corporation from
the enemy south, has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to
install docks, build a domed theater and a spa with a glass atrium,
pave roads, and string electric cables. Hyundai has plans for a
1,000-room seaside hotel, a 45-hole golf course and a ski slope. It
has done all this with the blessing of the north's reclusive
Communist leaders. The project is the biggest gamble taken so far
that north and south, which technically are still at war, will
peacefully reunify. By Calvin Sims.

   (ART ADV: Photo has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

   QWEST-MARKETPLACE (Undated) _ If Qwest Communications
International Inc. had not agreed to acquire US West Inc., Qwest
probably would have announced a deal to be acquired by Deutsche
Telekom of Germany by now, and at a healthy premium to Qwest's
stock market value. For Qwest's top executives, that has to hurt.
Not only have they failed to grasp a highly lucrative opportunity
with the German company, but more important, the hurdles standing
in their way are strictly of their own making. By Seth Schiesel.

   COIN-AD-COLUMN (Undated) _ A wry, sly and totally fly version of
George Washington _ portrayed in contemporary pursuits from dining
on Chinese takeout to surfing to riding the subway _ is the focus
of an atypically offbeat campaign from the federal government,
promoting use of the new dollar coin. By Stuart Elliott.

     CULTURE (Moved in ``e'' category)  

   OKEEFFE-FAKES (Undated) _ Arts in America: Some Georgia O'Keeffe
watercolors may be fakes. By Gretchen Reynolds.

   BELIEVE-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Make Believe,'' by Joanna
Scott (Little Brown). Reviewed by Michiko Kakutani.

   TV-SECRET-REVIEW (Undated) _ On UPN, ``Secret Agent Man.''
Reviewed by Ron Wertheimer.

     COMMENTARY (Moved in ``k'' category)   

   COLLINS-COLUMN (Undated) _ Gail Collins provides some highlights
of the presidential campaign thus far.

   FRIEDMAN-COLUMN (Undated) _ Thomas L. Friedman criticizes
opposition to a trade bill that would aid African clothing
manufacturers.

     SPORTS (Moved in ``s'' category)  

   BBA-ARATON-COLUMN (Undated) _ Sports of The Times column on the
Yankees, who are starting to look a little gray around the edges.
By Harvey Araton.

   FBN-VIKINGS-MARINO (Undated) _ It now appears that there may be
life after the Dolphins for veteran quarterback Dan Marino. Instead
of announcing his retirement, Marino now appears set to join the
Minnesota Vikings, a playoff-caliber team that might provide the
38-year-old quarterback with one more shot at the Super Bowl. By
Thomas George.

     SCIENCE TIMES (Moved in ``a'' category)   
  

   SCI-BRENNER-BIOTECH (La Jolla, Calif.) _ Sydney Brenner, who is
now the inventor-guru of a new biotechnology company after retiring
from the British Medical Research Council, has been a leading
molecular biologist for nearly half a century. In a career of
unquenchable creativity, he has always kept moving, searching for
new and different problems to tackle, founding a new field as soon
as old one seemed stale. By Nicholas Wade.

   SCI-GAMMA-RAYS (Undated) _ While the fate of the crippled
Compton Gamma Ray Observatory remains up in the air, NASA moved
last week to ensure the continued study of the powerful and
mysterious radiations that appear to signal the most violent
phenomena in the distant universe by selecting Stanford University
to develop and build the main instrument for the Gamma Ray Large
Area Space Telescope, better known by the acronym GLAST. By John
Noble Wilford.

   (ART ADV: Photo [NYT2) has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

   SCI-HERBAL-SUPPLEMENTS (Undated) _ Experts on herbal supplements
call for stronger government regulation of their manufacture and
sale, but concede that `the horse is out of the barn' as far as
their popularity among consumers goes. By Denise Grady.

   (ART ADV: Photo [NYT1) has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

   SCI-SLEEP-LEARNING (Undated) _ Scientists have discovered a new
link between sleep and memory that seriously challenges the wisdom
of skimping on snooze time each night. Experiments show that when
people learn a new skill, their performance does not improve until
after they've had more than six and preferably eight hours of
sleep. Without adequate sleep, researchers say, skills and even new
factual information may not get properly encoded into the brain's
memory circuits. By Sandra Blakeslee.

   SCI-LONGEVITY-ETHICS (Philadelphia) _ As scientists work hard to
figure out how cells, organisms or even people might become more or
less immortal, ethicists meet to declare that life expectancies in
the U.S. are long enough already and that tinkering with death
could have disastrous consequences. 900 words. By Nicholas Wade.

   SCI-QUANTUM-COMPUTERS (Undated) _ Talks at a recent quantum
computer conference centered on algorithms for quickly solving
problems thought infeasible for ``classical'' computers,
understanding the limits of the computational power of quantum
computers, various approaches to building a practical device and
methods for correcting computational errors. The week culminated in
a series of presentations to a financing agency of the Defense
Department. By Sara Robinson.

   SCI-CHAUCER (Undated) _ With the sweet showers of April soon to
arrive, piercing the drought of March as little birds make melody,
scientists are longing to make pilgrimmages into the works of
Geoffrey Chaucer, who wrote on highly technical subjects as well as
penning The Canterbury Tales. By James Glanz.

   SCI-FIRES-COMPUTERS (Undated) _ Researchers at the National
Institute of Standards and Technology have a new sophisticated
computer model to reconstruct fatal fires and to perform other
complex fire-related problems including predicting the performance
of ceiling sprinklers and to explaining why a sprinkler next to one
already active fails to open in proper sequence _ a phenomenon
known as sprinkler skip. By Mark Derr.

   (ART ADV: Photo [NYT3) has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

   SCI-RHYTHMIC-CLAPPING (Undated) _ Researchers in the United
States, Romania and Hungary think they understand why order can
arise spontaneously in a cheering crowd. The phenomenon of rhythmic
clapping, the scientists reported last month in the journal Nature,
follows a mathematical model for what are known as coupled
oscillators. But it also has cultural roots. By Henry Fountain.

   SCI-WATCH (Undated) _ News and notes on science: Items on new
insights on development of tools and other implements in China,
sonar fish surveys and rediscovered moons of Uranus. By Henry
Fountain.

   SCI-REITERS-DISEASE (Undated) _ One of the greatest honor for
doctors and researchers is having something named after them,
including a disease. Now, some in the field are calling for
Reiter's syndrome to be renamed. First, Dr. Reiter didn't really
discover it in the first place. And, he was heavily involved in
deadly human experiments in Nazi death camps, new evidence reveals.
By Lawrence K. Altman.

   SCI-PLASTINATING-BODIES (Undated) _ The University of Michigan
has begun carrying out a process known as plastination on a
larger-scale basis, plastinating an entire human body. Usually,
only parts are involved, then sold for study to medical students.
By Mary Roach.

   SCI-CIRCUS-CLASSES (Undated) _ Adults can indulge in childhood
fantasies and join the circus, for an hour or so in circus classes
that focus on acrobatics. By Alison Hendries.

   (ART ADV: Photo has been sent to NYT photo clients.)

   SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ Personal Health: Far too many
parents fail to use proper restraints when their children ride in a
car, despite all the laws and warnings. The problem is especially
serious with children ages 4 to 8, who have outgrown their safety
seats. By Jane E. Brody.

   SCI-Q&A (Undated) _ A science question answered: Are caribou the
same as reindeer? Answer: They are very closely related. By C.
Claiborne Ray.

     NYT News Service
